Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone-induced ethylene and foliar injury responses are altered in 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate synthase antisense potato plants.

AbstractText: •  In potato (Solanum tuberosum), two 1-aminocyclopropane-1-carboxylate synthase (ACS) genes are induced by ozone (O<sub>3</sub> ). Antisense inhibition of these ethylene (C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> ) biosynthetic genes allowed us to examine the relationship between O<sub>3</sub> -induced C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> emission and foliar injury. •  Thirty-two lines (antisense for ST-ACS4 or ST-ACS5) were screened in the glasshouse for acute O<sub>3</sub> -induced C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> and lesions. Stomatal conductance and ACS transcripts were quantified for selected C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> -altered lines. Six lines were field-tested for chronic O<sub>3</sub> effects. •  Ten lines produced less, and four lines produced more, acute-O<sub>3</sub> -induced C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> than nontransformed (NT) plants. Ethylene levels did not appear to be correlated with stomatal conductance. ST-ACS4 and -5 transcript were reduced in transgenic plants, except in two C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> over-producing lines. In the field, these C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> over-producing lines displayed stunting and leaf rolling in charcoal-filtered (CF) air and chronic O<sub>3</sub> , and they sustained the most severe O<sub>3</sub> injury. •  When C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> production was strongly suppressed or enhanced, corresponding reductions or increases in lesion severity were observed, suggesting a critical role for C<sub>2</sub> H<sub>4</sub> in the lesion formation process during O<sub>3</sub> stress.
